body:
I am confused why your system is fetching the source package. Can you download the wheel manually from PyPI and force the binary install by pip install-ing the actual local binary file?

I suspect you need the equivalent to zlib-dev library to be able to build from source. 

(Also, please try 1.14.1, as that's our latest version ;) )

@mehrdada I get the same error with `1.14.1`

I believe there is no binary wheel that's compatible with Mac OS 10.13 (there's a 10.12 one though). Perhaps that's why it's falling back to source. Let me try to use the docs to verify if I have the right toolchain to build from source.

I tried to `brew install` the packages in the docs and set the corresponding environment variables, but wasn't able to get a successful build. I could take a stab at creating a 10.13 wheel. Do you have any pointers for how to configure the build scripts to generate one?

That would be weird--I just tested a pip install on a High Sierra machine and it worked.  I think at least the default Python is fine with fetching the existing macOS wheel. Have you tried downloading the 10.12 wheel and installing it via pip? (`pip install filename`) 

What's your pip version? (`pip freeze`)

For instructions building from source try: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/tree/master/src/python/grpcio

My env:

```console
$ pip freeze
enum34==1.1.6
futures==3.2.0
six==1.11.0
$ pip --version
pip 18.0 from /Users/maxr/.pyenv/versions/2.7/envs/py2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pip (python 2.7)
```

I'm unable to install the 10.12 wheel:

```console
$ pip install --verbose grpcio-1.14.1-cp27-cp27m-macosx_10_12_x86_64.whl
Created temporary directory: /private/var/folders/sy/m5m3sx7j7pd8st25jcn21y580000gq/T/pip-ephem-wheel-cache-zxbA8I
Created temporary directory: /private/var/folders/sy/m5m3sx7j7pd8st25jcn21y580000gq/T/pip-req-tracker-MUimnl
Created requirements tracker '/private/var/folders/sy/m5m3sx7j7pd8st25jcn21y580000gq/T/pip-req-tracker-MUimnl'
Created temporary directory: /private/var/folders/sy/m5m3sx7j7pd8st25jcn21y580000gq/T/pip-install-G94lH3
Cleaning up...
Removed build tracker '/private/var/folders/sy/m5m3sx7j7pd8st25jcn21y580000gq/T/pip-req-tracker-MUimnl'
grpcio-1.14.1-cp27-cp27m-macosx_10_12_x86_64.whl is not a supported wheel on this platform.
Exception information:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/maxr/.pyenv/versions/2.7/envs/py2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pip/_internal/basecommand.py", line 141, in main
    status = self.run(options, args)
  File "/Users/maxr/.pyenv/versions/2.7/envs/py2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pip/_internal/commands/install.py", line 274, in run
    self.name, wheel_cache
  File "/Users/maxr/.pyenv/versions/2.7/envs/py2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pip/_internal/basecommand.py", line 216, in populate_requirement_set
    requirement_set.add_requirement(req_to_add)
  File "/Users/maxr/.pyenv/versions/2.7/envs/py2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pip/_internal/req/req_set.py", line 71, in add_requirement
    wheel.filename
InstallationError: grpcio-1.14.1-cp27-cp27m-macosx_10_12_x86_64.whl is not a supported wheel on this platform.
```

pip filters out the wheels as well

```console
$ pip install --no-cache-dir --verbose grpcio==1.14.1 2>&1 | grep 'Skipping.*1.14.1.*macosx.*x86_64'
    Skipping link https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/77/a1/a587467be4cc44219425968a0620629d044bac787388fc1bc52fae6ee0e8/grpcio-1.14.1-cp27-cp27m-macosx_10_12_x86_64.whl#sha256=3a3baa77bd1183e963766f57a70475b970c8b20462f77e497b6062197c134437 (from https://pypi.org/simple/grpcio/); it is not compatible with this Python
    Skipping link https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/fd/49/69c8b0e963566fe02f0d215b42bf95c9fd0d8f3e85b1649470684adac723/grpcio-1.14.1-cp37-cp37m-macosx_10_9_x86_64.whl#sha256=bbbd2a993747e312fba0d7b6497a2b5c403d67995e0c59218ffe35dabe1121ff (from https://pypi.org/simple/grpcio/); it is not compatible with this Python
```

To see what tags pip supports, run this:

```bash
# requires pip > 10, not testing on anything > 18.0
python -c 'from pip._internal.pep425tags import get_supported; import pprint; pprint.pprint(get_supported())'
```

Looks like there aren't any 64-bit Mac OS entries 😵
@mxr Where did you get your Python distribution?
`pyenv` through https://github.com/pyenv/pyenv-installer, not sure how I ended up with 32-bit Python after that 😅
I'm closing this issue as we don't support 32-bit Python on macOS. Please feel free to ping if you had any problems installing on a 64-bit Python on macOS.

For closure, `pyenv install 2.7` installs `2.7.0` (thought it would install the latest), which results in this behavior. `pyenv install 2.7.15` installs 64-bit Python. Thanks @asottile for root causing!
I don't personally use `pyenv`, but I reported an issue to them: https://github.com/pyenv/pyenv/issues/1198
